questions.question: Are the three top portions of the candelabra replaced with transparent, tapered glass perfume caps?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the tops of the candelabra are shaped like tapered glass, resembling perfume caps. They appear transparent and have a pointed design typical of perfume bottle stoppers. This is not a typical design for a candelabra, indicating an edit to resemble perfume caps.

questions.question: Have the curved arms connecting the top portions been replaced with sleek, seamless gold-finish tubing?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the arms of the candelabra are sleek and have a seamless appearance with a gold finish. This contrasts with more traditional designs which might have more transitions or detailing. The smooth and polished nature of the arms signifies an edit for a more modern and elegant appearance.

questions.question: Is there a minimalist brand logo embossed on the base of the object?
questions.explanation: On the base of the candelabra in Image B, the word 'CANDELABRA' is embossed, which seems to act as a brand or decorative text. The text is minimalistic in nature, fitting the criteria of a brand logo.

questions.question: Are intricate floral-engraved patterns visible across the surface of the object?
questions.explanation: The surface of the candelabra in Image B displays intricate floral-engraved patterns, particularly noticeable on the central tube and base, which provide a decorative, detailed look to the object, indicating the edit includes detailed engravings.

questions.question: Is there a subtle, elegant script font label positioned on the central tube of the object?
questions.explanation: There is a label on the central tube of the candelabra in Image B, which displays the text 'Candelabra' in an elegant script font. The positioning and type of font highlight the subtleties a decorative label would include.
